p:
Some patients still tested positive after recovering from COVID-19 [42], [83]. The biological process underlying viral rebound is unknown. Our simulation in Fig. 6A shows that if the value of
σ
is small, i.e. the clearance rate of infected cells increases slowly as the adaptive immune response emerges, then a second viral peak is predicted because the adaptive immune response is not sufficient to control the viral replication. Thus, viral rebound that lasts for a period of time can be observed. As
δ
( t) increases to above a certain level, the viral load will decline again and eventually be eliminated ( Fig. 6A).
